articles.title: ‚ÄòCosby Show' actor Geoffrey Owens shares life update after Trader Joe's job
creator: Gabrielle Chung | E! Online
articles.description: Originally appeared on E! OnlineNo job is too small for Geoffrey Owens.That‚Äôs why ‚ÄúThe Cosby Show‚Äù alum returned to work at Trader Joe‚Äôs after he was job-shamed by online critics in 2018.‚ÄúTrader Joe‚Äôs was a wonderful job,‚Äù he said in a recent interview with V-103 Atlanta‚Äôs ‚ÄúBig Tigger Morning Show.‚Äù ‚ÄúI‚Äôve gone back there since all happened. And basically, I asked for hours to work there again.‚ÄùWhile Owens didn‚Äôt specify if he is still an employee at the grocery store, he did share insight into why he initially left his post amid ‚Äúscrutiny‚Äù over his day job.‚ÄúI‚Äôm a very private person,‚Äù he explained. ‚ÄúIt wasn‚Äôt like I quit knowing that I was going to be making a lot of money soon or anything. I just felt like I wasn‚Äôt going to be able to handle that kind of attack on my privacy.‚ÄùBut the 63-year-old has no problem working for an honest pay. After all, as he put it, his residual checks from ‚ÄúThe Cosby Show‚Äù were ‚Äúnever particularly wonderful.‚ÄùREAD Cosby Show Star Geoffrey Owens Speaks Out After Being Job-Shamed‚ÄúI did maybe 20 percent of the show,‚Äù he noted. ‚ÄúPeople have a false you impression of what the average middle class actor makes and their ability to make a living in the industry. That‚Äôs what drove me to work at Trader Joe‚Äôs to begin with.‚ÄùOwens continued, ‚ÄúBut honestly, I‚Äôm not much better off now.‚ÄùIn fact, the actor ‚Äî whose recent credits include ‚ÄúPoppa‚Äôs House‚Äù and ‚ÄúMr. Santa: A Christmas Extravaganza‚Äù ‚Äî said he‚Äôs still dealing with financial hardships.‚ÄúEven today, right now, as we speak, I still struggle to make a living,‚Äù he shared. ‚ÄúI struggle every day to make my ends meet. And people can‚Äôt get their heads around that because they see me in movies.‚ÄùStill, Owens is ‚Äúnot complaining‚Äù about his situation.‚ÄúI‚Äôm grateful for the work I have,‚Äù he added. ‚ÄúI work more than a lot of people do, so I got to keep perspective.‚Äù

articles.title: GOOD NEWS! Central government employees may get 3% DA HIKE in January 2025
articles.description: The Dearness Allowance (DA) for state government employees remains uncertain. However, a DA increase for central government employees in January is almost certain, with speculation rife about the percentage. The central government increases the DA for its employees twice a year, in January and July. The central government increased DA by 3% during Diwali. Currently, central employees receive 53% DA. Speculation is rife about when the central government will announce the next DA increase, typically twice a year, in January and July. The DA increase is effective from January to June and from July to December. Speculation has begun on the DA increase percentage for the new year, following a 3% increase in October. Reports suggest the AICPI index reached 144.5 by October, potentially leading to a 55.05% DA increase. If the index reaches 145.3 by December, a 56% DA increase is possible in January 2025. The central government has not made any official announcement yet. A 3% DA increase would mean a Rs 540 raise for employees with a basic salary of Rs 18,000 and Rs 270 for pensioners receiving Rs 9,000. With current minimum/maximum salaries at Rs 18,000/Rs 250,000 and pensions at Rs 9,000/Rs 125,000, a 3% DA hike translates to a Rs 7,500/Rs 3,750 increase respectively.

articles.title: Delhi: Rain Disrupts Traffic, Triggers Waterlogging. IMD Issues Orange Alert As More Showers Likely
creator: ABP News Bureau
articles.description: An 'orange' warning was issued in Delhi after rain lashed several parts of the national capital and adjoining areas on Friday, disrupting traffic in multiple locations. The India Meteorological Department (IMD) has forecast more showers during the day. Visuals circulating on social media platforms showcased heavy rainfall in Delhi, with severe waterlogging reported in areas like Burari.#WATCH | Heavy water logging witnessed in the Burari area as rain continues to lash parts of Delhi. pic.twitter.com/RL2u3V3tiD‚Äî ANI (@ANI) December 27, 2024The rain, which began around 2:30 am, affected traffic flow in south, central, and north Delhi. #DelhiRains | Rain lashes parts of #Delhi and NCR Heavy water logging witnessed as rain continues to lash parts of Delhi. #DelhiNCR pic.twitter.com/zyXTCjM7cI‚Äî DD India (@DDIndialive) December 27, 2024According to IMD data till 11:30 am, rainfall was recorded at several observatories across the city. The Safdarjung observatory, Delhi‚Äôs primary weather station, reported 9.1 mm of rain, while Palam recorded 8.4 mm, Lodhi Road 10.8 mm, Ridge 9 mm, Delhi University 11 mm, and Pusa 9.5 mm. VIDEO | Delhi: Rain lashes parts of the national capital. Visuals from Kartavya Path and Rafi Marg.(Full video available on PTI Videos - https://t.co/n147TvrpG7) pic.twitter.com/1fp0aixhBu‚Äî Press Trust of India (@PTI_News) December 27, 2024ALSO READ | Winter Chill Bites As Rain Drenches Parts Of Delhi-NCR, AQI Remains 'Very Poor'Orange Alert For Rain In DelhiThe weather office attributed the rain to an active western disturbance and its interaction with easterly winds, which is causing light to moderate rainfall and thunderstorms across northwest and central India, including Delhi-NCR, news agency PTI reported. The 'orange' warning issued by the IMD indicates preparedness for potentially hazardous weather. The minimum temperature in the national capital was recorded at 11 degrees Celsius, 2.8 degrees above normal. Air quality in Delhi remained a concern, with the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) reporting an AQI of 372 at 9 am, categorised as 'very poor'. On Thursday, the 24-hour AQI stood at 345. An AQI between 301 and 400 is classified as 'very poor', indicating possible health effects, especially for vulnerable groups. The IMD has predicted light to moderate rain for the rest of the day, advising residents to be cautious amidst ongoing weather conditions.

articles.title: Azerbaijan Airlines suspends flights to Russian cities after plane crash
articles.description: Azerbaijan's flag carrier announced Friday that it will suspend flights to several Russian airports, citing potential flight safety risks after a crash of one of its planes that many experts blamed on Russian air defence fire.Azerbaijan Airlines' Embraer 190 was flying from Azerbaijan's capital of Baku to the Russian city of Grozny in the North Caucasus on Wednesday when it was diverted for reasons still unclear and crashed while making an attempt to land in Aktau in Kazakhstan after flying east across the Caspian Sea. The crash killed 38 people and left all 29 survivors injured.Authorities in Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan and Russia were tight-lipped about a possible cause of the crash pending an official probe, but a lawmaker in Azerbaijan blamed Moscow. Rasim Musabekov told the Azerbaijani news agency Turan on Thursday that the plane was fired on while in the skies over Grozny, and urged Russia to offer an official apology.Asked about Musabekov's statement, Kremlin spokesman Dmitry .

articles.title: Current account deficit moderated marginally to US$ 11.2 billion in Q2FY25
articles.description: According to latest data from RBI, India's current account deficit (CAD) moderated marginally to US$ 11.2 billion (1.2 per cent of GDP) in Q2:2024-25 from US$ 11.3 billion (1.3 per cent of GDP) in Q2:2023-24. Merchandise trade deficit increased to US$ 75.3 billion in Q2:2024-25 from US$ 64.5 billion in Q2:2023-24. Net services receipts increased to US$ 44.5 billion in Q2:2024-25 from US$ 39.9 billion a year ago. Services exports have risen on a y-o-y basis across major categories such as computer services, business services, travel services and transportation services.

articles.title: Economist Dr Rathin Roy Pays Tribute To The Visionary Former Prime Minister Dr. Manmohan Singh
articles.description: In this exclusive segment with Rahul Kanwal, renowned economist Dr. Rathin Roy, former Member of the PM's Economic Advisory Council, delves into Dr. Manmohan Singh's remarkable contributions to India's economic and political landscape. From pioneering the 1991 economic liberalization to steering the nation through global financial crises, Dr. Singh's visionary leadership redefined India's trajectory. Dr. Roy sheds light on Singh's unparalleled intellect, humility, and dedication to public service, which inspired a generation. The discussion explores Singh's academic brilliance, his transformative role in financial system reforms, and his adaptability in various economic roles. As an unelected Prime Minister, Singh's ability to lead, build effective teams, and manage crises left an indelible impact on India's prosperity and global standing.

articles.title: Olympic silver medallist Aran Zalewski to captain Kalinga Lancers in HIL
creator: Sambad English Bureau
articles.description: Rourkela: Kalinga Lancers have announced Tokyo Olympics silver medallist and three-time Olympian Aran Zalewski as their captain. The former co-captain of the Kookaburras brings a wealth of experience, having played a pivotal role in the Australian hockey team's success.The recently retired Australian captain will assume charge of the team effective immediately as they prepare for their inaugural game in the Hockey League against UP Rudras on December 30.The Kalinga Lancers, now owned by Vedanta, showcase an impressive combination of seasoned players like Thierry Brinkman and Alexander Hendrickx, alongside rising Indian talents such as Krishan Pathak, Rosan Kujur, and Sanjay. The team will be coached by German maestro Valentin Altenburg.Announcing their captain Vedanta Kalinga Lancers coach Valentin Altenburg said, "With a squad packed with superstars and natural leaders, selecting a captain is a challenge any coach would love to have. Aran‚Äôs exceptional mastery of the game speaks for itself, and his leadership since becoming co-captain of the Australian team in 2018 has been nothing short of inspiring. While our squad boasts a wealth of experience and incredible potential, we believe Aran is the perfect fit to lead this talented group as we look to build on Odisha‚Äôs proud legacy in hockey and are focused on bringing home the title."Aran expressed his delight in taking up the role of Kalinga Lancers captain, "I‚Äôm truly grateful for the opportunity the team has given me. We have an incredible mix of talent, and it‚Äôs an honor to share the dressing room with players like Thierry, Krishan, Sanjay, and the younger boys. Representing Bhubaneswar‚Äôs team is a matter of immense pride, especially since Odisha is the heartbeat of hockey in India. We‚Äôre all eager and ready to take charge on the field and give our best for the fans and the legacy of this great state."The team gathered in Bhubaneswar last week, where, in the presence of all 16 Indian players from the squad, Kalinga Lancers unveiled their new jersey, anthem, and mascot. The home jersey showcases a striking blend of blue and green, while the away jersey retains the vibrant orange and white.The new design thoughtfully integrates elements of history, art, geography, and progress, paying homage to Odisha‚Äôs rich heritage while reflecting its forward-looking aspirations.Squad:Defenders: Sanjay, Mandeep Mor, Alexander Hendrickx, Arthur Van Doren, Antoine Kina, Partap Lakra, Sushil Dhanwar, Rohit KulluMidfielders: Aran Zalewski, Moriangthem Rabichandra, Enrique Gonzalez, Mukesh Toppo, Rosan Kujur, Nicholas BandurakForwards: Boby Singh Dhami, Dilpreet Singh, Thierry Brinkman, Angad Bir Singh, Roshan Minz, Gursahibjit Singh, Deepak PradhanGoalkeepers: Krishan Pathak, Tobias Reynolds-Cotterill, Sahil Kumar Nayak(IANS)

articles.title: If interest rates remain ‚Äòhigher for longer,' the winners are those with cash accounts
creator: Greg Iacurci,CNBC
articles.description: The Federal Reserve in December projected fewer interest rate cuts for 2025. Yields on high-yield savings accounts, money market funds, certificates of deposit and other cash-like accounts should benefit from this ‚Äúhigher for longer‚Äù rate environment.Many people, especially those with debt, will be discouraged by the recent Federal Reserve forecast of a slower pace of interest rate cuts than previously forecast.However, others with money in high-yield cash accounts will benefit from a ‚Äúhigher for longer‚Äù regime, experts say.‚ÄúIf you‚Äôve got your money in the right place, 2025 is going to be a good year for savers ‚Äî much like 2024 was,‚Äù said Greg McBride, chief financial analyst at Bankrate.Why higher for longer is the 2025 ‚Äòmantra‚ÄôReturns on cash holdings are generally correlated with the Fed‚Äôs benchmark interest rate. If the Fed raises interest rates, then those for high-yield savings accounts, certificates of deposit, money market funds and other types of cash accounts generally rise, too.The Fed increased its benchmark rate aggressively in 2022 and 2023 to rein in high inflation, ultimately bringing borrowing costs from rock-bottom rates to their highest level in more than 22 years. It started throttling them back in September. However, Fed officials projected this month that it would cut rates just twice in 2025 instead of the four it had expected three months earlier.‚ÄúHigher for longer is the mantra headed into 2025,‚Äù McBride said. ‚ÄúThe big change since September is explained by notable upward revisions to the Fed‚Äôs own inflation projections for 2025.‚ÄùThe good and bad news for consumersThe bad news for consumers is that higher interest rates increase the cost of borrowing, said Marguerita Cheng, a certified financial planner and CEO of Blue Ocean Global Wealth in Gaithersburg, Maryland.‚Äú[But] higher interest rates can help individuals of all ages and stages build savings and prepare for any emergencies or opportunities that may arise ‚Äî that‚Äôs the good news,‚Äù said Cheng, who is a member of CNBC‚Äôs Financial Advisor Council.More from Personal Finance:Credit card debt set to hit record levelsMore than 90% of 401(k) plans now offer Roth contributionsWhy the ‚Äògreat resignation‚Äô became the ‚Äògreat stay‚ÄôHigh-yield savings accounts that pay an interest rate between 4% and 5% are ‚Äústill prevalent,‚Äù McBride said.By comparison, top-yielding accounts paid about 0.5% in 2020 and 2021, he said.The story is similar for money market funds, he explained.Money market fund interest rates vary by fund and institution, but top-yielding funds are generally in the 4% to 5% range.However, not all financial institutions pay these rates.The most competitive returns for high-yield savings accounts are from online banks, not the traditional brick-and-mortar shop down the street, which might pay a 0.1% return, for example, McBride said.Things to consider for cashThere are of course some considerations for investors to make.People always question which is better, a high-yield savings account or a CD, Cheng said.‚ÄúIt depends,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúHigh-yield savings accounts will provide more liquidity and access, but the interest rate isn‚Äôt fixed or guaranteed. The interest rate will fluctuate, nor your principal. A CD will provide a fixed guaranteed interest rate, but you give up liquidity and access.‚ÄùAdditionally, some institutions will have minimum deposit requirements to get a certain advertised yield, experts said.Further, not all institutions offering a high-yield savings account are necessarily covered by Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. protections, said McBride. Deposits up to $250,000 are automatically protected at each FDIC-insured bank in the event of a failure.‚ÄúMake sure you‚Äôre sending your money directly to a federally insured bank,‚Äù McBride said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd avoid fintech middlemen that rely on third-party partnerships with banks for FDIC insurance.‚ÄùA recent bankruptcy by one fintech company, Synapse, highlights that ‚Äúunappreciated risk,‚Äù McBride said. Many Synapse customers have been unable to access most or all of their savings. creator: ABP News Bureau
articles.description: Keshav Prasad Maurya paid tribute to former Prime Minister Manmohan Singh, highlighting his invaluable contributions in various roles, including as the Governor of the Reserve Bank of India, Finance Minister, and Prime Minister. Despite facing numerous challenges, Singh made critical decisions that helped propel the nation forward. Maurya emphasized that during a time when India‚Äôs economy was on the brink, with a foreign exchange reserve of just one billion dollars, Singh‚Äôs leadership was instrumental in restoring stability. His economic reforms and visionary leadership helped revive India‚Äôs financial system, and his dedication to the country‚Äôs growth remains a defining aspect of his legacy. Maurya acknowledged that Singh‚Äôs efforts were crucial in reshaping India‚Äôs economic landscape.

articles.title: Gunaah Season 2: Surbhi Jyoti and Gashmeer Mahajani starrer show's latest instalment to start streaming from January 3
articles.description: Disney+ Hotstar is thrilled to bring back the much-loved Gunaah with its highly anticipated second season, premiering exclusively from January 3, 2024, onwards. This season takes the intensity up a notch, delving deeper into a gripping tale of revenge, betrayal, and love. With more twists, emotional drama, and shocking revelations, it promises to keep viewers on the edge of their seats. Starring Abhimanyu (Gashmeer Mahajani), Tara (Surbhi Jyoti), JK (Darshan Pandya), and Michael (Shashank Ketkar) amongst others, the show releases from January 3, 2024 onwards.Director Anil Senior said, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm beyond excited to bring Gunaah Season 2 to our audience. After the overwhelming success of Season 1 on Disney+ Hotstar, we knew we had to raise the stakes even higher. This season isn‚Äôt just about revenge and betrayal; it‚Äôs about exploring the raw, unfiltered emotions of each character. Their journeys are more complex, and I believe viewers will truly connect with the depth of their struggles. It‚Äôs been a thrilling challenge to push the boundaries of storytelling and create an even more intense and immersive experience. I can‚Äôt wait for everyone to see what we‚Äôve put together.‚ÄùMautik Tolia, Producer and Managing Director at Bodhitree Multimedia, added, ‚ÄúThe return of Gunaah with its second season is a reflection of the incredible response and love the audience has given to this series. At Bodhitree Multimedia, we strive to create stories that resonate deeply and Gunaah is no exception. This season delves into the complexities of human relationships, blending intense drama with emotions that are both raw and real. It has been an rewarding journey bringing this story to life and we are thrilled to take audiences on another unforgettable ride.‚ÄùSurbhi Jyoti, who plays Tara, expressed, ‚ÄúSeason 1 introduced everyone to Tara‚Äôs world‚Äîher struggles, her relationships, and the weight of her choices. But Season 2 is on a whole new level. Tara is thrown into situations that challenge everything she stands for, pushing her strength and emotions to their very limits. The twists in her relationship with Abhimanyu are heart-wrenching and raw, and I think anyone who has ever wrestled with love, guilt, or redemption will deeply connect with her story. I‚Äôm so excited for audiences to see this side of her‚Äîit‚Äôs emotional, intense, and full of surprises!‚ÄùGashmeer Mahajani, who plays Abhimanyu, shared, ‚ÄúAbhimanyu‚Äôs journey in Gunaah Season 2 is nothing short of extraordinary. This time, his choices are more difficult, his struggles are more profound, and his vulnerabilities are laid bare. It was both challenging and rewarding to portray his evolution, especially as he navigates the tumultuous relationships and high-stakes decisions that define this season. I‚Äôm confident that viewers will resonate with the complexities of his character and the emotional depth of his story.‚Äù View this post on Instagram A post shared by Disney+ Hotstar (@disneyplushotstar)Also Read: Photos: Krishna Shroff, Nimrit Kaur Ahluwalia, Gashmeer Mahajani, Sumona Chakravarti and others attend the Khatron Ke Khiladi 14 event in Mumbai

articles.title: 15 Years of 3 Idiots EXCLUSIVE: Ali Fazal says, "Aamir Khan has been a great mentor at different stages of my life"; HILARIOUSLY reacts to 'Sir, Mirzapur mein Drone fek ke dikhao' meme
articles.description: Ali Fazal made his Bollywood film debut with 3 Idiots (2009) and immediately caught the attention of the industry and fans, despite limited screen time. Ali played the role of Joy Lobo, who dies by suicide after being demotivated by the college dean, played by Boman Irani. His demise forms an important part of the film as it talks about the burning issue of student suicides. Even after 15 years, when reports of students ending their lives emerge, one can‚Äôt help but remember Ali Fazal‚Äôs track in 3 Idiots, which proves its impact.Bollywood Hungama exclusively spoke to Ali Fazal recently and reminded him that 3 Idiots will complete 15 years on December 25. Ali was stunned by this information. When asked how he looks back at the film, he replied, ‚ÄúIt did what it did at that time for me. I thank the makers for it. Vidhu sir (Vidhu Vinod Chopra) is somebody I‚Äôd love to come back and work with. I had a small role but he made sure that the soul of that part remains in the film. And it did and it worked. I thank him and Raju sir (Rajkumar Hirani).‚Äù3 Idiots also starred Aamir Khan in the lead role. Life came full circle for Ali Fazal as he collaborated with the superstar in Lahore 1947, one of the most awaited films of 2025. On this, he said, ‚ÄúOur bond has been amazing. He has been a great mentor at different stages of my life. I thank him for that. Lahore 1947 has been a wonderful experience.‚ÄùAli Fazal also revealed that he hasn‚Äôt completed its shoot yet saying, ‚ÄúA few days of the shoot remains. I (couldn‚Äôt shoot before as I) got busy with Mani Ratnam sir‚Äôs Thug Life.‚Äù Directed by Rajkumar Santoshi, Lahore 1947 also stars Sunny Deol and Preity Zinta.In 3 Idiots, Joy Lobo designs a drone camera but since he fails to submit the project on time, he is failed by college director Dr Viru Sahastrabuddhe aka Virus. Hence, Joy is devastated and ends his life. Ali Fazal in recent times was seen in Mirzapur as a dreaded gangster. Hence, a famous internet meme shows Joy telling Virus, ‚ÄúSir, kabhi Mirzapur mein aake mera drone fek ke dikhao, fir dekho‚Äù!When asked Ali Fazal about it, he couldn‚Äôt stop laughing and said, ‚ÄúYeah I have seen it and it is so funny man! Somebody sent it to me while shooting. I love the meme culture. People are quite creative.‚ÄùMirzapur, Fukrey updatesMirzapur has become an iconic show and fans are excited to know that Mirzapur The Film is in the offing. Will there be another season of Mirzapur along with the film? Ali Fazal answered, ‚ÄúI believe so but I don‚Äôt know about it. What I do know is that we are focusing on the film and plan to get it on floors as soon as the script is looked.‚ÄùWill he be back in Fukrey 4? He said, ‚ÄúYes, if it happens. Par ab kitni Fukrey banayenge? (laughs)‚Äù. When said that he was missed in the third part and there were whistles for him in the end credit scene, he said, ‚ÄúI know and we did readings as well. I was supposed to do it but then I got busy with Vishal ji‚Äôs film, Khufiya (2023). Due to the pandemic, things got pushed. Also, half of my time was devoted to Mirzapur. So, I had to opt out. The makers allowed me as the other stalwarts of the film were there.‚ÄùDigital release at last for Girls Will Be GirlsMeanwhile, Ali Fazal is happy with the premiere of his first production Girls Will Be Girls on Amazon Prime Video, which he made along with his wife Richa Chadha. Despite being a very Indian story, it made waves in film festivals across the world.He said, ‚ÄúAny story that is rooted in emotions will always make sense anywhere in the world. That is the power of cinema or should I say, the hack of cinema. It‚Äôs a great lesson for the scriptwriters that they should stay true to their story and their roots. This is because you know them well. Writer-director Shuchi Talati knows that world well. We have also grown up in the 90s.‚ÄùAli continued, ‚ÄúFor one of the screenings at Sundance, we just went to see the audience reaction. People were reacting as if they were watching a thriller! People were even relating to cute moments like when the girls tells the guy to cut the call after one ring.‚ÄùHe signed off by saying, ‚ÄúI really thank Amazon for championing this project. It sends the right message to young and offbeat filmmakers that there‚Äôs a space for such films.‚ÄùAlso Read: 15 Years of 3 Idiots EXCLUSIVE: Sharman Joshi recalls unexpected fame in China-Hong Kong, thanks to Aamir Khan-starrer: ‚ÄúThey recognized me, gave me FREE drinks everywhere!‚Äù

articles.title: EXCLUSIVE: Manisha Koirala on the changing times in cinema, "Pehle achhe gaane hote the, abhi woh missing hai"
articles.description: Cinema has always mirrored the changing times, evolving alongside societal shifts. Over the years, the way films are made, consumed, and experienced has transformed drastically, with both positive and negative implications. Some industry veterans and actors like Manisha Koirala, Nawazuddin Siddiqui, Shriya Pilgaonkar and Kritika Kamra recently shared their thoughts on this evolution in an exclusive interview with Bollywood Hungama, highlighting the contrasts between the past and present.From Lost Poetry to Realism in PerformancesManisha Koirala, nostalgically reflected on what has been lost in modern cinema. She noted, ‚ÄúMusic and poetry is missing,‚Äù a sentiment many fans of older films might share. ‚ÄúPehle achhe gaane hote the, thehraav hota tha, abhi woh missing hai‚Äù. She added, ‚ÄúEverything is robotic now, we used to be relaxed earlier,‚Äù pointing to the more mechanical, fast-paced nature of modern filmmaking.The rise of digital platforms and social media has also altered personal connections. Koirala emphasized, ‚ÄúWe had human bondings earlier and today it‚Äôs just the feedback through social media,‚Äù illustrating the shift from real-world connections to online interactions. Despite these changes, Koirala said, ‚ÄúThe pace is good now, I like it,‚Äù and expresses, ‚ÄúI love the realism in the performance and takes nowadays.‚ÄùChanging Dynamics of Personal Connections in CinemaShriya Pilgaonkar mentioned, ‚ÄúAaj kal log darr gaye hain that we will be misunderstood,‚Äù revealing how fear of judgment has impacted modern performances. She also highlighted by saying, ‚ÄúAbhi everyone has their own people and their own circle.‚Äù This sentiment is echoed by Nawazuddin Siddiqui, who remarked, ‚ÄúPehle industry mein bonds bante the, ab no one has time.‚ÄùShift Away from Emotional Depth and ConnectionsKritika Kamra observed a troubling trend and said, ‚ÄúNow it is glorification of hustle culture.‚Äù The evolution of cinema presents a complex picture. While there are undeniable advances in technology, performance, and storytelling, many lament the loss of the emotional depth and bonds that once defined the industry.Also Read: Manisha Koirala expresses happiness as she reunites with Mani Ratnam at IFFI Goa

articles.title: One Good Thing: This is what made us happy in 2024
creator: The Associated Press
articles.description: People around the world suffered an average of 41 extra days of dangerous heat this year because of human-caused climate change, according to a group of scientists who also said that climate change worsened much of the world‚Äôs damaging weather throughout 2024.The analysis from World Weather Attribution and Climate Central researchers comes at the end of a year that shattered climate record after climate record as heat across the globe made 2024 likely to be its hottest ever measured and a slew of other fatal weather events spared few.‚ÄúThe finding is devastating but utterly unsurprising: Climate change did play a role, and often a major role in most of the events we studied, making heat, droughts, tropical cyclones and heavy rainfall more likely and more intense across the world, destroying lives and livelihoods of millions and often uncounted numbers of people,‚Äù Friederike Otto, the lead of World Weather Attribution and an Imperial College climate scientist, said during a media briefing on the scientists‚Äô findings. ‚ÄúAs long as the world keeps burning fossil fuels, this will only get worse.‚ÄùMillions of people endured stifling heat this year. Northern California and Death Valley baked. Sizzling daytime temperatures scorched Mexico and Central America. Heat endangered already vulnerable children in West Africa. Skyrocketing southern European temperatures forced Greece to close the Acropolis. In South and Southeast Asian countries, heat forced school closures. Earth experienced some of the hottest days ever measured and its hottest-yet summer, with a 13-month heat streak that just barely broke. climate changeSep 18Studies reveal drastic increase in deaths related to extreme heatExtreme WeatherSep 3Extreme heat worsens chronic health conditions in millions of AmericansTo do its heat analysis, the team of volunteer international scientists compared daily temperatures around the globe in 2024 to the temperatures that would have been expected in a world without climate change. The results are not yet peer-reviewed, but researchers use peer-reviewed methods.Some areas saw 150 days or more of extreme heat due to climate change.‚ÄúThe poorest, least developed countries on the planet are the places that are experiencing even higher numbers,‚Äù said Kristina Dahl, vice president of climate science at Climate Central. What‚Äôs worse, heat-related deaths are often underreported. ‚ÄúPeople don‚Äôt have to die in heat waves. But if we can‚Äôt communicate convincingly, ‚Äòbut actually a lot of people are dying,‚Äô it‚Äôs much harder to raise this awareness,‚Äù Otto said. ‚ÄúHeat waves are by far the deadliest extreme event, and they are the extreme events where climate change is a real game changer.‚ÄùThis year was a warning that the planet is getting dangerously close to the Paris Agreement‚Äôs 1.5 degrees Celsius (2.7 degrees Fahrenheit) warming limit compared to the pre-industrial average, according to the scientists. Earth is expected to soon edge past that threshold, although it‚Äôs not considered to have been breached until that warming is sustained over decades.The researchers closely examined 29 extreme weather events this year that killed at least 3,700 people and displaced millions, and found that 26 of them had clear links to climate change.The El NinÃÉo weather pattern, which naturally warms the Pacific Ocean and changes weather around the world, made some of this weather more likely earlier in the year. But the researchers said most of their studies found that climate change played a bigger role than that phenomenon in fueling 2024‚Äôs events. Warm ocean waters and warmer air fueled more destructive storms, according to the researchers, while temperatures led to many record-breaking downpours.Jennifer Francis, a climate scientist at the Woodwell Climate Research Center in Cape Cod who wasn‚Äôt involved in the research, said the science and findings were sound.‚ÄúExtreme weather will continue to become more frequent, intense, destructive, costly, and deadly, until we can lower the concentration of heat-trapping gases in the atmosphere,‚Äù she said.Significantly more climate extremes could be expected without action, the United Nations Environment Programme said in the fall, as more planet-warming carbon dioxide has been sent into the air this year by burning fossil fuels than last year.But the deaths and damages from extreme weather events aren‚Äôt inevitable, said Julie Arrighi, director of programmes at the Red Cross Red Crescent Climate Centre and part of the research. ‚ÄúCountries can reduce those impacts by preparing for climate change and adapting for climate change, and while the challenges faced by individual countries or systems or places vary around the world, we do see that every country has a role to play,‚Äù she said.

articles.title: IRCTC launches ‚ÄòSuper App': Know about Indian Railway Travel Booking and Services
articles.description: Booking train tickets is now easier than ever, thanks to the new IRCTC app. Many passengers rely on the IRCTC app for booking, and this new version offers significant improvements. Indian Railways launches a new app called Super IRCTC for ticket booking, PNR status checks, ordering food, and travel planning. The Super IRCTC app provides unprecedented features and conveniences for passengers. Book long-distance train tickets quickly and easily with the Super IRCTC app. Get real-time train tracking information and estimated arrival times. Book hotels, holiday packages, and order meals through the Super IRCTC app. Download the free Super IRCTC app on Android and iOS for a seamless travel experience. Check train seat availability and detailed route information within the Super IRCTC app. The Super IRCTC app simplifies train ticket booking with its all-in-one platform.

articles.description: Manmohan Singh death: The Union Cabinet, chaired by Prime Minister Narendra Modi, passed a condolence resolution in memory of former Prime Minister Dr Manmohan Singh. The Cabinet paid homage to Dr Singh by observing a two-minute silence. A seven-day state mourning has been declared until January 1, 2025.

articles.title: Elon Musk, Vivek Ramaswamy expose rift with MAGA loyalists over immigrant tech workers
creator: Katherine Doyle, David Ingram and Elyse Perlmutter-Gumbiner | NBC News
articles.description: People around the world suffered an average of 41 extra days of dangerous heat this year because of human-caused climate change, according to a group of scientists who also said that climate change worsened much of the world‚Äôs damaging weather throughout 2024.The analysis from World Weather Attribution and Climate Central researchers comes at the end of a year that shattered climate record after climate record as heat across the globe made 2024 likely to be its hottest ever measured and a slew of other fatal weather events spared few.‚ÄúThe finding is devastating but utterly unsurprising: Climate change did play a role, and often a major role in most of the events we studied, making heat, droughts, tropical cyclones and heavy rainfall more likely and more intense across the world, destroying lives and livelihoods of millions and often uncounted numbers of people,‚Äù Friederike Otto, the lead of World Weather Attribution and an Imperial College climate scientist, said during a media briefing on the scientists‚Äô findings. ‚ÄúAs long as the world keeps burning fossil fuels, this will only get worse.‚ÄùMillions of people endured stifling heat this year. Northern California and Death Valley baked. Sizzling daytime temperatures scorched Mexico and Central America. Heat endangered already vulnerable children in West Africa. Skyrocketing southern European temperatures forced Greece to close the Acropolis. In South and Southeast Asian countries, heat forced school closures. Earth experienced some of the hottest days ever measured and its hottest-yet summer, with a 13-month heat streak that just barely broke. Climate ChangeSep 18Studies reveal drastic increase in deaths related to extreme heatExtreme WeatherSep 3Extreme heat worsens chronic health conditions in millions of AmericansTo do its heat analysis, the team of volunteer international scientists compared daily temperatures around the globe in 2024 to the temperatures that would have been expected in a world without climate change. The results are not yet peer-reviewed, but researchers use peer-reviewed methods.Some areas saw 150 days or more of extreme heat due to climate change.‚ÄúThe poorest, least developed countries on the planet are the places that are experiencing even higher numbers,‚Äù said Kristina Dahl, vice president of climate science at Climate Central. What‚Äôs worse, heat-related deaths are often underreported. ‚ÄúPeople don‚Äôt have to die in heat waves. But if we can‚Äôt communicate convincingly, ‚Äòbut actually a lot of people are dying,‚Äô it‚Äôs much harder to raise this awareness,‚Äù Otto said. ‚ÄúHeat waves are by far the deadliest extreme event, and they are the extreme events where climate change is a real game changer.‚ÄùThis year was a warning that the planet is getting dangerously close to the Paris Agreement‚Äôs 1.5 degrees Celsius (2.7 degrees Fahrenheit) warming limit compared to the pre-industrial average, according to the scientists. Earth is expected to soon edge past that threshold, although it‚Äôs not considered to have been breached until that warming is sustained over decades.The researchers closely examined 29 extreme weather events this year that killed at least 3,700 people and displaced millions, and found that 26 of them had clear links to climate change.The El NinÃÉo weather pattern, which naturally warms the Pacific Ocean and changes weather around the world, made some of this weather more likely earlier in the year. But the researchers said most of their studies found that climate change played a bigger role than that phenomenon in fueling 2024‚Äôs events. Warm ocean waters and warmer air fueled more destructive storms, according to the researchers, while temperatures led to many record-breaking downpours.Jennifer Francis, a climate scientist at the Woodwell Climate Research Center in Cape Cod who wasn‚Äôt involved in the research, said the science and findings were sound.‚ÄúExtreme weather will continue to become more frequent, intense, destructive, costly, and deadly, until we can lower the concentration of heat-trapping gases in the atmosphere,‚Äù she said.Significantly more climate extremes could be expected without action, the United Nations Environment Programme said in the fall, as more planet-warming carbon dioxide has been sent into the air this year by burning fossil fuels than last year.But the deaths and damages from extreme weather events aren‚Äôt inevitable, said Julie Arrighi, director of programmes at the Red Cross Red Crescent Climate Centre and part of the research. ‚ÄúCountries can reduce those impacts by preparing for climate change and adapting for climate change, and while the challenges faced by individual countries or systems or places vary around the world, we do see that every country has a role to play,‚Äù she said.

articles.title: In states that ban abortion, social safety net programs often fail families
creator: Laura Ungar, Kimberlee Kruesi | Associated Press
articles.description: Taylor Cagnacci moved from California to Tennessee with hopes of starting a new chapter in a state that touts a low cost of living and natural beauty. But she‚Äôs infuriated by Tennessee‚Äôs meager social services, which leave her and many other moms struggling in a state where abortion is banned with limited exceptions.‚ÄúI was going to have my child no matter what, but for other women, that‚Äôs kind of a crappy situation that they put you in,‚Äù said Cagnacci, a 29-year-old Kingsport mom who relies on Medicaid and a federally funded nutrition program. ‚ÄúYou have to have your child. But where‚Äôs the assistance afterward?‚ÄùTennessee has a porous safety net for mothers and young children, recent research and an analysis by The Associated Press found. It‚Äôs unknown how many women in the state have given birth because they didn‚Äôt have access to abortion, but it is clear that from the time a Tennessee woman gets pregnant, she faces greater obstacles to a healthy pregnancy, a healthy child and a financially stable family than the average American mom. abortionDec 23Abortion opponents shift focus to pills with lawsuits, proposed laws and possible federal actionabortionDec 13Texas' abortion pill lawsuit against New York doctor marks new challenge to interstate telemedicineabortionNov 26Why abortions rose after Roe was overturnedLike other states with strict abortion bans, Tennesseans of childbearing age are more likely to live in maternal care deserts and face overall doctor shortages. Women, infants and children are less likely to be enrolled in a government nutrition program known as WIC. And Tennessee is one of only 10 states that hasn‚Äôt expanded Medicaid to a greater share of low-income families.‚ÄúIt‚Äôs survival, every day,‚Äù said Janie Busbee, founder of Mother to Mother, a Nashville-based nonprofit providing baby supplies for low-income moms. ‚ÄúIf we took some of that stress off of them, then maybe they‚Äôd have time to dream.‚ÄùGOP state leaders in Tennessee and other states that banned abortion after the U.S. Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade in 2022 argue that they are bolstering services for families. Tennessee boosted its Medicaid coverage for mothers in 2022 from 60 days postpartum to a year, which allowed an additional 3,000 moms to use the program each year.The state also raised the Medicaid income limit for parents to the poverty level ‚Äî nearly $26,000 for a family of three ‚Äî and offers recipients 100 free diapers a month for babies under 2. According to the governor‚Äôs office, these changes have resulted in thousands of new parents accessing government services.‚ÄúPro-life is much more than defending the lives of the unborn,‚Äù Republican Gov. Bill Lee said in his 2023 annual address to lawmakers and echoed more recently on social media. ‚ÄúThis is not a matter of politics. This is about human dignity.‚ÄùYet, nonprofit leaders and mothers told the AP there are still significant gaps in the safety net. Anika Chillis, a 39-year-old single mom in Memphis, has Medicaid, WIC and the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (formerly known as food stamps). While she‚Äôs deeply grateful for the help, she said it also can disappear ‚Äî like when she temporarily lost WIC.‚ÄúIt‚Äôs hard,‚Äù she said, sitting on a park bench as her 2-year-old son and 9-year-old daughter played nearby. ‚ÄúGroceries are constantly going up.‚Äù And being a single mom ‚Äúmakes it doubly hard on you.‚ÄùMedicaid and health care challengesTennessee fared poorly at WIC enrollment, Medicaid, having enough maternal care and requirements for paid family and medical leave, an October study found. Other states with similarly restrictive abortion laws ‚Äî such as Idaho, Alabama, Missouri, Georgia and Mississippi ‚Äî ranked poorly on numerous measures, too. Researchers said restrictive states had a slightly higher average birth rate and a much lower average abortion rate than the least restrictive states.‚ÄúIn general, these states that restrict abortion are the more fiscally conservative, the more socially conservative states,‚Äù said Dr. Nigel Madden, lead author of the study published in the American Journal of Public Health. The Republican supermajority in the Tennessee legislature has long rebuffed efforts to expand Medicaid to people earning up to 138% of the federal poverty level ‚Äî about $35,600 for a family of three. And TennCare faces criticism already, with a federal judge ruling earlier this year that the state unlawfully terminated coverage for thousands of families and had a ‚Äúlethargic‚Äù response to nearly 250,000 children losing coverage because of paperwork problems caused by the state.DiJuana Davis, 44, was among the plaintiffs. In 2019, the Nashville resident was supposed to have surgery to prevent pregnancy and ease her chronic anemia. Days before the procedure, she was informed her Medicaid coverage had been cut off and the hospital was canceling. She later found out her renewal paperwork went to the wrong address, an error that left her uninsured for two months ‚Äî during which she became pregnant and developed preeclampsia. Doctors induced labor to save her life, and her son was born prematurely.‚ÄúThe system is broken,‚Äù she said, ‚Äúand it needs to be fixed.‚ÄùMore than 3% of the 83,000 babies born in Tennessee in 2023 had mothers who didn‚Äôt receive prenatal care. Only seven states had a higher share, according to an AP analysis of data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.After birth, doctor shortages impede ongoing care. Around a third of Tennesseans live in a primary care shortage area ‚Äî a greater share than in all but 10 other states ‚Äî according to an AP analysis of data from the Census Bureau and the Health Resources and Services Administration. Food and diaper programsMoms described several aid programs as frustrating to navigate. Chillis was on WIC for several months after her son was born, but then went without because of a mistake during the renewal process ‚Äî eventually getting it restored with help from the nonprofit Tennessee Justice Center.Chillis credits a nonprofit preschool provider with linking her to aid programs in the first place: ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt see a lot of advertisements about, you know, how you can join this program or go get this‚Äù service, she said. ‚ÄúPeople just don‚Äôt have the knowledge.‚ÄùCagnacci, who is pregnant and has a 1-year-old, said she was on SNAP for a while but missed an appointment and was unclear about the steps after that. The process to get recertified was ‚Äúsuch a headache‚Äù that she‚Äôs going without it.‚ÄúI just felt like it was purposely being made difficult so that I would just give up,‚Äù she said.Women with young children in states where abortion is banned or limited to early weeks of pregnancy said it can be tough to get social services there, according to a survey by the health policy research organization KFF. Nearly half said it‚Äôs difficult for women in their state to get food stamps, for example, compared with 3 in 10 in states where abortion is generally available.‚ÄúPeople who claim to be pro-life, who advocated for these abortion bans, often suggest that these policies are designed to protect children, women and families,‚Äù said Madden, the researcher. But the weakness of the safety net shows ‚Äúthe hypocrisy of that argument.‚ÄùTennessee‚Äôs new diaper program shows the deep political divisions surrounding aid programs. The Republican governor described it as an effort to strengthen families while Democratic state Sen. London Lamar said GOP leaders are ‚Äútrying to put a little bow on an abortion ban.‚Äù And GOP state Sen. Mark Pody recently told the right-leaning news website Tennessee Conservative that ‚Äúit is not the state‚Äôs responsibility to have a diaper for every single baby‚Äù and floated the possibility of cutting the program. Charities struggle to fill gapsOf Tennessee‚Äôs 2.8 million households, 30% earn above the poverty level but not enough to afford the basic cost of living in their counties, according to a recent report. Often, they don‚Äôt qualify for government help.‚ÄúSome are working three jobs and still can‚Äôt survive,‚Äù said Busbee, of Mother to Mother.A fragmented patchwork of charities can help, but they don‚Äôt cover the entire state. The Nashville Diaper Connection, for example, serves 30 counties, working with partners to provide 50 diapers a month, mostly to working families who make a bit too much for Medicaid. Other nonprofits are hindered in helping by government agencies‚Äô income rules. And most charities are constrained by the ebb and flow of donations.Nonprofit leaders fear their job may get harder with a new administration in Washington and a GOP-controlled Congress. Republicans could seek significant changes to federal assistance programs they‚Äôve long criticized, like Medicaid and food stamps.‚ÄúWe‚Äôve been through four years of a Trump administration, and the goal under the Trump administration was to cut social services,‚Äù said Signe Anderson, the justice center‚Äôs senior director of nutrition advocacy. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm concerned ... for families in Tennessee and across the country.‚Äù___Kruesi reported from Nashville, Tennessee. AP data journalists Kasturi Pananjady and Nicky Forster contributed to this report. ‚Äî‚ÄîThe Associated Press Health and Science Department receives support from the Howard Hughes Medical Institute‚Äôs Science and Educational Media Group and the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation. The AP is solely responsible for all content.

articles.title: U.S. Dollar Surges Amid Global Economic Shifts
articles.description: U.S. Dollar Surges Amid Global Economic Shifts The U.S. dollar is poised for an impressive 7% annual increase, with Japan's yen enduring yet another year of losses. Traders attribute the dollar's strength to anticipated solid U.S. economic growth, prompting the Federal Reserve to proceed cautiously on rate cuts, potentially extending into 2025.The dollar index recorded a slight rise as the currency approached significant monthly and yearly gains, while the yen faced considerable declines. Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell highlighted the central bank's cautious stance on further rate cuts, fueling trade activity in major markets.Global economies brace for the impact of President-elect Donald Trump's proposed policies, perceived to be both growth-stimulating and inflationary. Market watchers expect the Bank of Japan to maintain its monetary stance and predict further easing by the European Central Bank as the eurozone experiences economic slowdown.

articles.title: Tragedy strikes off Morocco coast as migrant boat capsizes, killing 69 people
articles.description: Tragedy struck off the coast of Morocco when a makeshift boat carrying around 80 people, mostly from West Africa, capsized while en route to Spain. The mishap has claimed the lives of at least 69 people, including 25 Malians, according to Mali's authorities. Only 11 people survived the ordeal, with at least nine of them being from Mali. Also Read: South Korean opposition votes for impeachment of current president Han Duck-Soo; Here's what happens next The boat capsized last week (Dec 19), but the Ministry of Malians Abroad confirmed the incident on Thursday. A crisis unit has been dispatched to monitor the situation. This tragic event highlights the dangers of migrant crossings from Africa to Europe. Mali has been plagued by years of jihadist and separatist violence, and there were military coups in 2020 and 2021. The country's instability, coupled with unemployment and the effects of climate change on farming, has driven many to seek better opportunities in Europe. However, the journey is perilous, with over 10,000 people having lost their lives attempting to reach Spain by boat from Africa this year, according to Spanish rights charity Caminando Fronteras. This averages out to around 30 deaths per day, making this migration route one of the most treacherous in the world. The route spans from the Atlantic coasts of Mauritania and Morocco to Spain, with many migrants hailing from sub-Saharan Africa, fleeing poverty and conflict in their home countries. Morocco's proximity to Spain, just eight nautical miles apart at their closest point, makes it a popular departure point for migrants. Also Read: 'Greatest champion of India-US partnership': US diplomat Antony Blinken's tribute to Manmohan Singh

articles.title: Mahakumbh 2025: Yogi Govt plans world record eye test & glass distribution; ‚ÄòNetra Kumbh‚Äô to be inaugurated on Jan
creator: WEB DESK
articles.description: Under the leadership of Chief Minister Yogi Adityanath, the Mahakumbh 2025 will make history with the goal of setting several world records, including one for conducting eye tests and distributing glasses. The upcoming ‚ÄúNetra Kumbh‚Äù (Eye Kumbh) event, to be inaugurated on January 5, 2025, aims to provide eye tests for 500,000 individuals and distribute over 300,000 glasses, marking the largest eye care initiative of its kind. The Netra Kumbh, located on a sprawling 10-acre site near the Nagvasuki Temple, is set to become a landmark event in the field of public health. This initiative, a first in history, aims to provide free eye tests to half a million devotees and distribute 300,000 pairs of glasses during the event. Organisers have set a target of 10,000 eye tests per day to achieve the ambitious goal. The event will also offer free medicines alongside eye tests and glasses distribution. Dr. Ranjan Bajpai, a member of the organising committee, shared that the inaugural ceremony of the Netra Kumbh will be led by Acharya Mahamandaleshwar Avdheshanand Giri Maharaj of Juna Akhada, with Maharaj Gaurang Prabhu Ji and Dr. Krishna Gopal Ji, Sangh‚Äôs Saha Sarkaryavah, as special guests. Last time, the event was recognised by the Limca Book of World Records, and efforts are underway to secure a place in the Guinness World Records this time. The Netra Kumbh is set up with high-level infrastructure, including 11 hangars, a significant increase from the five hangars in the previous event. Each hangar will serve as a station for eye tests, with dedicated OPD chambers for registration and doctor consultations. The organisers have partnered with 240 hospitals across India, bringing doctors from various regions to provide specialised care. Rajesh Kumar Singh, in charge of crowd management, revealed that arrangements for the accommodation and food of the doctors have been made, with 40 dormitories for doctors, and separate facilities for female doctors and volunteers. Additionally, 16-bed dormitories for pilgrims and 8-bed dormitories for volunteers are also available. A key feature of the Netra Kumbh will be the establishment of a special eye donation camp, inspired by Emperor Harshvardhan of Prayagraj‚Äôs charitable legacy. As a part of the initiative, people across India and even from abroad are encouraged to pledge eye donations. The importance of eye donation is underscored by the fact that over 1.5 crore people in India suffer from blindness, many of whom are in need of corneal transplants. Sunil Kumar Singh, a member of the organising committee, emphasised that previous Netra Kumbh events saw over 11,000 people pledge their eyes for donation. The organisers hope to continue this tradition and make a significant impact in the fight against blindness.

articles.description: Manmohan Singh, born in Punjab in 1932, served two terms as Prime Minister of India- from 2004 to 2014. He took the oath of office for the first time in 2004, after Congress' win in the 2004 Lok Sabha election against Atal Bihari Vajpayee-led NDA. He served his second term from 2009 to 2014. He was then succeeded by PM Narendra Modi in 2014.

articles.title: Nation Mourns Architect Of Economic Reforms, Former PM Manmohan Singh Passes Away At 92 | ABP News
creator: ABP News Bureau
articles.description: India mourns the loss of former Prime Minister Manmohan Singh, hailed as the architect of the nation‚Äôs economic reforms. The 92-year-old leader passed away last night at Delhi‚Äôs AIIMS hospital. Preparations for his funeral are underway, and it is expected to take place tomorrow. Tributes have been pouring in from across the country, with prominent political figures visiting his residence to pay their respects. Union Home Minister Amit Shah and BJP President J.P. Nadda were among the early visitors. Prime Minister Narendra Modi is expected to arrive shortly to offer his condolences. Manmohan Singh, known for his visionary leadership and transformative economic policies, leaves behind a legacy of progress and reform that reshaped modern India. The nation unites in grief to honor his memory and contribution.

articles.title: Azerbaijan Airlines Suspends Russian Flights Amid Crash Concerns
articles.description: Azerbaijan Airlines Suspends Russian Flights Amid Crash Concerns Azerbaijan's national airline has temporarily halted flight services to multiple Russian locations, following a deadly crash involving an Embraer 190 aircraft and suspected air defense interference.The incident, which claimed 38 lives and injured 29 people, occurred during a flight from Baku to Grozny, leading to heightened safety concerns after reports of GPS jamming and suspected air defense activities.Authorities from Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan, and Russia have launched a probe, while Russia has yet to officially address accusations. Flights to various locations remain suspended as the investigation unfolds, with Azerbaijan and international airlines evaluating safety protocols.

articles.title: 8 changes following NBC News' reporting on unclaimed bodies used for medical research
creator: Mike Hixenbaugh and Jon Schuppe | NBC News
articles.description: This article is part of ‚ÄúDealing the Dead,‚Äù an NBC News series investigating the use of unclaimed bodies for medical research.The revelation that a Texas medical school was routinely dissecting the bodies of unclaimed people and leasing them out to for-profit medical device companies for training and research drew a rapid and far-reaching response. NBC News‚Äô investigation into the University of North Texas Health Science Center led to changes even before the first article ran, with the center announcing in response to the reporters‚Äô findings that it was suspending its body donation program and firing the officials who led it. Medical technology companies that had received unclaimed bodies from the center also pre-emptively said they were changing policies or re-evaluating their work with the program. When the first part of the investigation was published online and aired on NBC‚Äôs ‚ÄúNightly News with Lester Holt,‚Äù elected officials at the local, state and federal level expressed alarm at what had occurred and said they would push for policy changes to prevent it from ever happening again. After obtaining the names of hundreds of people whose unclaimed bodies were sent to the Health Science Center, reporters discovered that some families had been unaware their relatives‚Äô bodies had been donated. To help survivors find answers, NBC News later published the names of the unclaimed dead, leading several more families to come forward, aghast at what they learned but grateful to finally know the truth. ‚ÄúHow does something like that happen?‚Äù Tim Leggett said after spotting the name of his brother, Denzil ‚ÄúDale‚Äù Leggett, on the list. ‚ÄúHow could somebody not realize, ‚ÄòHey, this person‚Äôs probably got family here?‚Äô‚Äù Tim Leggett learned of his brother‚Äôs death and donation to the Health Science Center from an article published by NBC News. (Zerb Mellish for NBC News)Here is more detail on the impact of NBC News‚Äô ‚ÄúDealing the Dead‚Äù series, which includes changes meant to ensure the bodies of the unclaimed dead are treated with respect and dignity in North Texas and beyond. 1. UNT‚Äôs Health Science Center fired officials and stopped accepting unclaimed bodiesThe University of North Texas Health Science Center initially defended its use of unclaimed bodies, but after NBC News presented its detailed findings, the center announced that it was suspending its body donation program, firing the officials who led it and hiring a consulting firm to investigate. ‚ÄúAs a result of the information brought to light through your inquiries, it has become clear that failures existed in the management and oversight of The University of North Texas Health Science Center‚Äôs Willed Body Program,‚Äù the center said in a statement. For years, the Health and Science Center acquired, studied and leased out the bodies of the unclaimed dead but abruptly halted the practice in September in response to an NBC News investigation. (Shelby Tauber for NBC News)Days later, the Health Science Center said it would stop accepting unclaimed bodies, explaining that its decision was based on information uncovered through reporters‚Äô requests. These documents detailed ‚Äúdeficiencies in leadership, standards of respect and care, and professionalism exhibited,‚Äù the center‚Äôs president, Sylvia Trent-Adams, wrote in an email to students, faculty and staff. University of North Texas spokesperson Andy North also apologized to families in a statement to NBC News: ‚ÄúThe Willed Body and BioSkills programs fell short of the standards of respect, care and professionalism that we demand. We are working to connect with families to extend our deepest apologies.‚Äù 2. Medical technology companies changed policies and cut ties with the Health Science CenterCompanies, teaching hospitals and medical schools that relied on the Health Science Center also took action. DePuy Synthes, a Johnson & Johnson company, said it had paused its relationship with the center. Boston Scientific said that it was no longer working with the center and that it had updated its global policy ‚Äúto require consent by the individual or next-of-kin.‚Äù Dr. Douglas Hampers, National Bioskills Laboratories‚Äô CEO, said his company would ensure that it no longer accepted unclaimed bodies. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think you have to violate a family‚Äôs rights in order to train physicians,‚Äù he said.In all, 10 organizations and companies said they did not know the center had provided them with unclaimed bodies.3. The Army said it would clarify its policies on unclaimed bodiesThe Army, which had received dozens of bodies and body parts from the Health Science Center, said it, too, was examining its reliance on the center‚Äôs Willed Body Program. The Army also said it planned to review and clarify internal policies on the use of unclaimed bodies.Separately, Terrence Hayes, spokesperson for the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs, offered condolences to the family of Victor Honey, a homeless veteran whose body was cut up and leased out to medical device companies and the Army without his consent or his relatives‚Äô knowledge.‚ÄúWe were extremely saddened to hear of his and his family‚Äôs story,‚Äù Hayes said in a statement. ‚ÄúMr. Honey, like all Veterans who have served our nation with courage and honor, deserved a dignified burial at the time of his passing.‚ÄùVictor Honey‚Äôs ex-wife, Kimberly Patman, and his son who shares his first and last name weren‚Äôt notified when Honey died. (Zerb Mellish for NBC News)4. Tarrant County made changes to treat the unclaimed dead with dignity Hundreds of unclaimed bodies flowed to the University of North Texas from Tarrant and Dallas counties, which saw the arrangement as a cost savings. The contracts the counties signed to turn over their unclaimed dead to the Health Science Center drew little scrutiny prior to NBC News‚Äô reporting. When reporters shared their findings ‚Äî including the stories of heartbroken family members ‚Äî with the top elected official in Tarrant County, Judge Tim O‚ÄôHare, he responded by saying that he planned to explore legal options ‚Äúto end any and all immoral, unethical, and irresponsible practices stemming from this program.‚Äù He called NBC News‚Äô reporting ‚Äúdisturbing, to say the least.‚Äù O‚ÄôHare followed up by leading the Tarrant County Commissioners Court in unanimously voting to adopt a new policy requiring officials to make more strenuous efforts to contact the deceased‚Äôs next of kin and to take their religious beliefs into account when deciding whether to bury or cremate them. Tarrant County commissioners adopted a policy meant to ensure unclaimed bodies are treated with dignity. (Shelby Tauber for NBC News)In addition, Tarrant County began publishing the names of unclaimed people on the National Missing and Unidentified Persons System, a free public database meant to connect reports of missing people to unclaimed bodies. Dallas County leaders said they also planned to review policies for handling unclaimed bodies.5. A Texas lawmaker announced a bill to ban medical research on unclaimed bodiesState Sen. Tan Parker, a Republican, announced plans to introduce a bill in the next legislative session in January to prohibit the use of people‚Äôs bodies for research unless they or their survivors give full consent. He said he had no idea before seeing NBC News‚Äô investigation that the Health Science Center had made money off of unclaimed bodies by dissecting them and leasing out the body parts. ‚ÄúI was outraged and completely just disgusted to see what had been occurring,‚Äù Parker said. ‚ÄúHuman life is sacred and needs to always be protected, and that is a core principle to me.‚ÄùTexas State Sen. Tan Parker pledged to outlaw the use of unclaimed bodies in Texas. (Texas Senate Media Services)6. Texas authorities ordered the Health Science Center to stop liquefying bodiesThe Texas Funeral Service Commission, which regulates body donation programs in the state, said it was conducting a review as well. The commission inspected the Health Science Center in October, after NBC News began publishing its investigation, and sent a cease-and-desist letter ordering the center to stop its practice of liquefying bodies after using them for training and research. The center had turned to alkaline hydrolysis, also known as water cremation, to save money, which the Funeral Commission said was illegal. ‚ÄúThis practice is not authorized under Texas state law and constitutes a serious violation of the standards governing the lawful disposition of human remains,‚Äù the commission said in the letter to Trent-Adams, the Health Science Center‚Äôs president.The center defended the legality of the practice in a statement to NBC News but said it had halted water cremations in September ‚Äî on the same day NBC News‚Äô investigation was published. 7. Members of Congress pressed local officials for informationU.S. Reps. Jasmine Crockett and Marc Veasey requested answers from officials in Dallas and Tarrant counties, saying they were ‚Äúshocked‚Äù by NBC News‚Äô investigation, including reporters‚Äô finding that the unclaimed bodies included veterans who are entitled to federal benefits that cover military funerals. In a letter to Dallas and Tarrant counties, they expressed particular concern that Victor Honey‚Äôs body had been used without anyone notifying his family that he was dead. ‚ÄúBy failing to contact Mr. Honey‚Äôs family, he was deprived of the rights he earned by bravely serving our country,‚Äù Crockett and Veasey wrote. ‚ÄúThis case alone raises serious concerns regarding how Dallas and Tarrant County investigators attempt to satisfy the ‚Äòdiligent inquiry‚Äô requirement set forth by state law.‚ÄùRep. Jasmine Crockett said she was ‚Äúshocked‚Äù by NBC News‚Äô investigation. (Al Drago / Bloomberg via Getty Images file)8. Families found long-sought answers about their relativesNBC News‚Äô reporting had a significant impact on families who hadn‚Äôt known what happened to their loved ones. As of December, reporters have identified at least 25 people whose bodies were sent to the Health Science Center without their relatives‚Äô knowledge; 11 of those people‚Äôs families learned details of what happened from NBC News.As a public service, NBC News published a list of more than 1,800 people whose bodies were sent to the Health Science Center, to help readers who are searching for answers about their loved ones. Noticias Telemundo, which is part of NBCUniversal, published a Spanish-language version of the list. Reporters heard from six readers who learned of their family members‚Äô death or donation when they discovered their names on the list.Nika Hodges‚Äô family had spent years searching for her before finding her name on the list of unclaimed bodies published by NBC News. (Courtesy Abigail Willson)‚ÄúWe didn‚Äôt know she was dead or what happened to her,‚Äù said Abigail Willson, whose mother, Nika Michelle Hodges, died at a Fort Worth hospice last year and whose body was then donated without her consent to the Health Science Center. ‚ÄúWe have searched everywhere, all over Texas. If you wouldn‚Äôt have put out that list of names, we never would have known.‚ÄùThis story originally appeared on NBCNews.com. Read more from the ‚ÄúDealing the Dead‚Äù series:As families searched, a Texas medical school cut up their loved onesThe body broker industry has no rules. For one disgraced chiropractor, that was perfect.A young woman‚Äôs body was chopped up for science ‚Äî as her mother desperately fought to bring her home
